content.value: In a mesmerizing 56 seconds of the semifinals at the 2024 World Crokinole Championship, Connor Reinman and Jason Slater simultaneously secured perfect rounds.

value.figcaption: Double perfect round. Watch on YouTube.

content.value: Technically speaking, they each flicked a 3.2cm disc 30cm across a board into a 3.5cm hole (just 9% wider than the disc itself) eight times in a row. In game terms, they made eight open 20s each; a rare gem of Crokinole perfection on display when the stakes couldn’t be higher.

How did we get here? How rare is a perfect round? Is Reinman vs. Slater the modern day Magic vs. Bird? Was this one of those obscure new Olympic events? You may even be wondering, “wtf is Crokinole?” If you find yourself sitting with any of these questions, then you’ve come to the right place.
20-second history

If you are from the southern region of the Canadian province of Ontario, you may already be well-versed in Crokinole due to its likely Canadian origin. But for the uninitiated, Crokinole is like a mashup of shuffleboard and curling, played on a tabletop board. It’s been around since the 19th century but has seen a steady rise in global popularity in recent years.

30-second game overview

Players take turns flicking discs toward the center, aiming to score high while knocking their opponent’s discs into lower zones or off the board. A shot must hit an opponent’s disc if one is present; otherwise, it must land in the inner circle (or score a 20 in the center hole). The round winner is whoever has the most points, and games consist of multiple rounds. Watch this video for a more thorough explanation of the rules.

The top players over the past decade
Connor Reinman, the back-to-back world champion, and Justin Slater, the perennial powerhouse, are arguably the greatest players on the Crokinole world stage right now.
But how good are they? Let's start by looking at their open 20 skills, an indispensable part of success.
Both Reinman and Slater are among the best competitive players at open 20s, making 66% and 75% respectively. An average competitive player makes around 55% of open 20s during in-game play.

To put this in perspective for some, a competitive player making eight consecutive 20s in live-game action is like an NBA player making 20 straight free throws during the course of a game (or games). Not impossible, but definitely not common either.
But it’s just flicking a little disc across a small table. How hard can it be, right?
Let's contextualize their skill by comparing it to some “ordinary” folks. Here is some data from a club of non-competitive players. Experience ranges from a handful to hundreds of games played.

Keep in mind that all of these percentages are based on in-game attempts, where a player’s open 20 rhythm is broken up by various other types of shots. In a vacuum, they can do some pretty impressive things. Take Shawn Hagarty for example, who recently set an unofficial world record of 64 straight open 20s.

content.value: Our theoretical scenarios give us a pretty good sense of the odds of seeing this phenomenon. It might seem surprising, but even a small drop in skill has a massive effect. But real games are much more nuanced and complex. A player — or their opponent — often misses quite early. Here is what the data suggests after reviewing X rounds from Y finals matchups from the past season’s tournaments.

value.caption: When the First Open 20 is Missed in Competitive Matches

content.value: A miss doesn’t fully close the door on a perfect round though. I’ve been framing this under the most elegant form of a “pure” double perfect round – where all 16 20s are made via open 20s. Technically you can still achieve a perfect round with a combination of open 20s and ricochet 20s. That opens up more complicated (but more exciting to watch) scenarios since going for a 20 may not be the best strategic choice.

But one thing remains clear; more skilled players are able to keep the number of discs on the board to a minimum and make open 20s at a higher rate, making it far more likely to see a perfect round when two great players go against each other.
And no, Crokinole isn’t an Olympic sport. Yet.
For more analysis, check out Shawn Hagarty’s visualizations.

text.value: Recreational open 20 success rates are based on observations of 600 open 20 attempts from 10 individuals with at least 50 attempts each.
